alert.note: Alert for Cabarrus (North Carolina) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Greenville-Spartanburg (Western North Carolina and Northwest South Carolina)
info.headline: Flash Flood Warning issued June 20 at 5:49PM EDT until June 20 at 10:00PM EDT by NWS Greenville-Spartanburg
info.description: ...FLASH FLOOD WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 10 PM EDT THIS EVENING FOR CABARRUS COUNTY... At 549 PM EDT, Emergency management is reporting several water rescues in the Kannapolis area. Thirty people were evacuated from a mobile home park along Irish Buffalo Creek at Tiffany Drive. No injuries occurred. Numerous roads are closed due to flooding in the vicinity including Louise Ave, Marie Ave, Waldorf Dr, Mable Ave, 22nd St, Pine St, Cadillac St, and Pump Station Rd. * Spillage at Lake Kannapolis Dam continues to increase, causing significant flows into Irish Buffalo Creek. These flows will continue to cause flooding of downstream locations along the creek, including C Street, Pump Station Rd, Tiffany Drive, Hunterridge Lane, Pine Street, and Rainbow Drive. * Exercise extreme caution when traveling in the Kannapolis area. Avoid all flooded roadways and obey all barricades. Stay away from all streams, but especially Irish Buffalo Creek. Significant flows will sweep away cars and persons caught in the flood waters. HAZARD...Life threatening flash flooding. Thunderstorms producing flash flooding. SOURCE...Emergency management reported. IMPACT...Life threatening flash flooding of creeks and streams, urban areas, highways, streets and underpasses. High flow going over Kannapolis Dam is causing downstream flooding along Irish Buffalo Creek, impacting roads, low-lying areas, and several low-lying structures including homes and businesses. Some locations that are experiencing flash flooding include... Kannapolis, Downtown Concord, West Concord, Harrisburg, Enochville, and Mt Pleasant. FLASH FLOOD...OBSERVED FLASH FLOOD DAMAGE THREAT...CONSIDERABLE
info.instruction: Turn around, don`t drown when encountering flooded roads. Most flood deaths occur in vehicles.
